work.name: Oracle (Cerner)
work.position: Technical Engagement Leader / Sr. Technical Engagement Leader
work.summary:
Responsible for the planning, coordinating, executing, running go-lives of technical projects for three major Oracle Cerner hosted clients in Australia. Queensland health (13k+ CCU - largest Australian client and 7th largest Cerner client), Alfred Health (2.5k CCU), and Western Health (1.8k CCU).

Projects varied from technically supporting major consulting projects with the introduction of new solutions/workflows, tech currency upgrades (Linux, Citrix, Windows, downtime solutions), BAU projects (Millennium release upgrades, Disaster Recovery testing, domain refreshes).
The largest project I delivered was a data centre migration (RHO flip) for Western Health that included a few technical upgrades, one of which was a CAMM migration to the cloud solution. The project was ran 100% remotely with team across Australia, India, and the US.

In addition to those responsibilities I championed and helped with the transition to Jira, Sprints, Config as Code (Github), Zabbix, Splunk, internal tools (JiraHelper, ACME), mentored associates to lead initiatives (Wiki with Hugo), ensured that lessons learned were tracked and shared globally.

work.name: Oracle (Cerner)
work.summary:
I have successfully delivered many projects, including mergers, Phase X RDDS projects, and roll outs. My responsibilities were to design and oversee the execution of domain, issue, and change management strategies; proactively identify and mitigate integration risks at both the project and program level; and manage complex client relationships across multiple stakeholders to guarantee objectives are delivered to ensure optimal clinical adoption

My most notable projects were:
  • Wirral Phase X introduced SurgiNet Anaesthesia, Critical Care and a first of type solution to UK clients, Oncology. Oncology required extra attention as the configuration was mainly delivered using RDDS (Reference Data Domain Synchronization) which hadn't been ever done.
  • Lewisham and Queen Elizabeth Merger where I organised Healthcare Executives, migration team, client stakeholder and define a strategy to resolve a show stopper issue regarding the migration of patient allergies.
Side projects:
  • I created an Excel tool in order to graphically display programme/project domain strategies
  • Improving the Data Quality by enhancing our internal tool

work.name: Oracle (Cerner)
work.summary:
I was responsible for the Design, Implementation, Audit and Troubleshooting of the Patient Registration Solution (ERM). The solution relied and impacted other areas of the EMR, I was also involved in troubleshooting ESM, CORE, FSI, CDS reporting, EKM rules.

I also improved standardisation across clients by documenting rules, and scripting the configuration extracts in order to automate it.
One of my best achievement was to resolve a data migration failure where 150000 records needed to be updated.

work.name: STMicroelectronics
work.summary: I planned and delivered a web solution to consolidate two e-form processes that tracked the quality of the production of silicon wafers. The process to create silicon wafers is long and any variation in steps outcome can lead to waste. Identifying issues early help reducing waste and cost. During the internship I interviewed internal customers, reported my weekly progress, and I conducted prototype testing workshops.

work.name: Orange
work.summary: I always reached and often exceeded my monthly sales goals.

work.name: Continental Automotive Systems
work.summary: I delivered two analysis to show differences between two existing information systems. This analysis aimed to define next steps of the project in order to migrate and consolidate one of the information system. I used UML diagrams (Use Case diagram; Class diagram; Sequence diagram; Communication diagram).

work.name: IT Tallaght
work.summary: I reversed engineered and delivered an educational software which taught implementation basis in 4 programming languages to university students (flowcharts; Turing machine; pseudo-code; assembly language). Once an algorithm was written, the user could run it step by step or in one go, and they could view their algorithm in the three other languages.
